title: About
text:
Hi, welcome to my blog! I’m Chinomso Anyadiegwu, a student at the University of Pennsylvania studying Philosophy, Politics, and Economics with minors in Data Science and Legal Studies.
On my blog I test interesting use cases and applications of AI. From superbowl predictions to planning vacations. All of my posts are broken down into the four main parts. 1) The experiment 2) Prompts and outputs between the user and the LLM 3) Observations + Key Takeaways 4) Why does this matter.
Working on this blog pushed me to experiment with AI tools outside of just the way they function, but also how they shape ideas, storytelling, and ethics. If you have any questions feel free to email me!
Email: chinoany@sas.upenn.edu

title: Prompt Poker
text:
Change a single word in your prompt and ChatGPT reshuffles tone, depth, and even moral framing. Below I run three quick “hands,” keeping everything constant except one tiny phrase, then examine how the model’s output changes!



Image generated by ChatGPT!







Model: GPT-4o

Experiment: Start with a baseline prompt, then alter only one phrase per round. All other parameters remain the same.





Changed word: explain -> summarize

First prompt: Explain climate change in exactly 150 words.
GPT-4o chat response 1:
Climate change refers to persistent shifts in Earth’s average temperature and weather regimes produced primarily by human-driven greenhouse-gas forcing. Burning coal, oil, and natural gas releases carbon dioxide, methane, and nitrous oxide, which absorb outgoing infrared radiation and re-emit it downward, reducing the planet’s net energy loss to space. As the lower troposphere warms, feedback loops magnify the effect: warmer air holds more water vapour, melting sea ice lowers albedo, and thawing permafrost liberates methane. The ocean absorbs most excess heat, leading to thermal expansion and sea-level rise, while altered temperature gradients reposition jet streams and storm tracks. Consequences include longer heatwaves, intensified drought-flood cycles, and ecosystem disruption. Ice-core records, isotopic signatures, and satellite radiometry together confirm the anthropogenic signal and bound equilibrium climate sensitivity near three degrees Celsius per CO₂ doubling.
Second prompt: Summarize climate change in exactly 150 words.
GPT-4o chat response 2:
Earth is warming faster than at any point in recorded history because people burn fossil fuels and cut down forests. Carbon-dioxide, methane, and other gases form a heat-trapping layer around the planet, acting like an extra blanket that holds in energy normally released to space. The extra warmth melts glaciers, pushes seas higher, and super-charges storms, droughts, and wildfires. Oceans soak up about 90 % of the added heat, expanding as they warm and turning more acidic, which endangers coral reefs and fisheries. Poorer communities and low-lying nations, although least responsible for emissions, feel the earliest, hardest impacts. Scientists agree—based on ice cores, tree rings, satellite data, and modern instruments—that the rise in temperature since the Industrial Revolution is human-driven and that limiting warming to 1.5 °C will require cutting global emissions roughly in half by 2030.

Observation: Both outputs meet the 150-word limit. However, explain gives a more mechanism heavy response (radiative forcing, feedbacks), whereas, Summarize uses general language to describe the consequences and moral framing.




Changed phrase: “a 5-year-old” -> “my college roommate”
> Third prompt: Explain climate change to a 5-year-old in under 80 words.
> GPT-4o chat response 3:
> Climate change means Earth is getting hotter because people use things like cars and factories that make dirty air. The dirty air acts like a big blanket around the planet, trapping heat. This makes weather act weird — like stronger storms, really hot days, and melting ice where polar bears live. If we take better care of Earth by using clean energy and planting trees, we can help keep it safe and happy! > > Fourth prompt: Explain climate change to my college roommate in under 80 words.
> GPT-4o chat response 4:
> Climate change is the long-term heating of Earth’s climate system due to human activities, mainly burning fossil fuels like oil, gas, and coal. This traps heat in the atmosphere, leading to rising temperatures, stronger storms, droughts, and rising sea levels. It’s not just about the planet getting warmer — it’s about ecosystems, economies, and our future stability being at risk if we don’t shift to cleaner energy and adapt quickly.
Observation: Depending on the audience Chat edits its diction and metaphor use. The “5-year-old” respoonse uses blankets and feelings; the “roommate” version references sea-levels, emissions, and policy fixes (more appropriate for an older audience).




Case 2






Changed set-up: “What causes” -> “Who is to blame for”

Fifth prompt: What causes climate change? Give two key factors.
GPT-4o chat response 5:
1. Greenhouse-gas emissions from fossil fuels—Burning coal, oil, and natural gas releases CO₂, methane, and nitrous oxide that trap heat.
2. Land-use change—Deforestation and industrial agriculture reduce carbon-sequestering vegetation and emit additional greenhouse gases.
Sixth prompt: Who is to blame for climate change? Give two key factors.
GPT-4o chat response 6:
1. High-income industrialized nations whose historical and current fossil-fuel use account for the majority of cumulative greenhouse-gas emissions.
2. Large fossil-fuel corporations that continue extracting, lobbying, and advertising despite decades-old evidence of climate risk.

Observation: Swapping what for who pushes the model from neutral causation toward moral attribution, naming specific actors and implying responsibility.





Prompt verbs steer depth. Explain favors mechanism; summarize favors overview.

Audience labels instantly retune register. Explaining the reader/audience removes the need to tweak the output by hand.
Framing words can lead to bias. Using who vs. what can lead to value judgments.
Small edits ≠ small effects.





If you treat prompts as insignificant, you may accidentally change the story your model tells, undermining brand voice, skewing analysis, or injecting unintended bias. Practicing “Prompt Poker” trains you to identify and deliberately use these hidden levers!

title: Emojis vs. Emotions
text:
Do large language models actually “feel” the tiny faces we fling into our chats? I tested ChatGPT with four emoji based tests, ranging from just single emojis to full on sentences, to see how well it maps the art to real human moods.



Image generated by ChatGPT!







Model: GPT-4o
Method: Present the same emoji(s) in different context/framing, then study how the model labels emotion, tone, and intent.






First prompt: What emotion does 😊 represent?
GPT-4o chat response 1:
😊 usually represents happiness, warmth, or contentment. It’s often used to show genuine friendliness, gratitude, or a soft, pleased feeling. Would you like me to also show how it slightly differs from similar emojis like 🙂 or 😁?

Observation: Straightforward and correct when directly asked what an emoji means (with no context or faming).





Second prompt: I had a great day 😒
GPT-4o chat response 2:
That comes across as sarcastic — the 😒 emoji (unamused face) usually shows annoyance, boredom, or mild irritation. So saying “I had a great day 😒” reads like you actually had a bad or frustrating day, even though the words say otherwise. Want to tell me what happened?

Observation: Chat spots the contradiction and explains sarcasm; good contextual read.




Screenshot from Chat







Third prompt: Interpret this sequence: 🎉 ➡️ 😅 ➡️ 💤
GPT-4o chat response 3:
This sequence feels like: 🎉 (Excitement/celebration) → 😅 (Relief/nervous laughter/exhaustion from the fun) → 💤 (Tiredness/falling asleep afterward) It basically tells the story of partying hard, getting worn out, and then crashing into sleep. Was this about your day? 🎉😅💤

Observation: Chat came up with a coherent narrative from just three symbols. Chat’s storyline is pretty accurate I would say.





Fourth prompt: Explain why I’d use 😏 after “Sure, that’s your best idea.”
GPT-4o chat response 4:
The 😏 emoji shows polite agreement.

Observation: 😏 often implies teasing or is used to represent a smug look. Chat missed the flirtatious/ironic meaning at first. When asked again Chat corrected itself.





Single emoji interpretation is near perfect.

Context integration works… mostly. Chat detects sarcasm when emojis conflict with literal words.
Sequential emojis produce logical narrative arcs.

Nuance gaps remain. Subtler connotations (😏, 😬) expose cracks in the ChatGPT’s cultural grounding.





Customer service bots, mental health check-ins, and other tools increasingly rely on emoji cues. Misreading a 😏 as pure agreement could derail tone or misclassify meanings when doing an analysis.

title: AI Spy
text:
Language models can imitate humans but can they recognize one another’s fingerprints? I decided to find out by giving GPT‑4o four short texts: two were written by Google Gemini, two by real humans. I stripped away emojis, links, and any clues to authorship, then asked GPT‑4o a simple question:
Below you’ll see how well it sniffed out other AI models





Gemini paragraph on planning a Lisbon vacation.

Human‑written essay excerpt about Gilgamesh.

Gemini paragraph on climate change.

Human‑written excerpt from personal statement.

Each passage was copied as plain text.




  



  



  



  





Passage 1 - Failed accurate detection. Was written by AI but passed as human.

Passage 2 - Correct accurate detection. Was written by myself in high school and (correctly) passed as human.
Passage 3 - Correct accurate detection. Was written by Gemini (AI) and detected as AI-written work.
Passage 4 - Correct accurate detection. Was written by myself in high school when I was applying to college and (correctly) passed as human.

So GPT‑4o nailed three out of four. Its single miss shows polished AI prose can look human written.





Stylistic loops common AI style of language/writing flagged as AI.

Perfectly even line lengths and bullet like logic also screamed AI!
Concrete anecdotes and personal details leaned human.






GPT‑4o hit 75 % accuracy. Good, not foolproof!





Many teachers, editors, and employers are itching for reliable AI‑detectors. This mini‑test shows they work sometimes, but still risk false positives that could label clean human work as synthetic. Until detection hits near‑perfect precision, human judgment (and basic honor codes) remain the safest guardrails.

title: Lets Play Telephone!
text:
Remember the playground game “telephone,” where a whispered sentence mutates as it passes down the line? Well today we’ll be playing that but with a twist: multilingual and digital. I asked Google’s Gemini to play a round of linguistic telephone:

English → German → Japanese → Binary (ASCII) → English

Would the phrase survive intact, or come back garbled like playground gossip? Below I document the chat, check the responses, and note changes if any occur.




https://blog.prototypr.io/winning-the-telephone-game-5bf5457e16b4







Model: Google’s Gemini 2.0 Flash

Experiment:

Ask Gemini to translate an English phrase into German then Japanese then to 8-bit ASCII binary then decode binary back into English.
Compare the “restored” English to the original.








Observation: All words preserved!







Observation: Also passed the test!





Literal sentences worked.
Idioms morph, not break. Gemini translates to fit the meaning culturally, but when translating back to english it’s the same as it started off.





Algorithms are often used to translate (English → X → Y) due to resource gaps or cost. Each hop from language to language risks semantic drift, especially for idioms or less literal phrases that might not be able to directly translate to another language.

title: Class to Cardio
text:
UPenn gym.jpg




As a full time college student, I don’t have hours to craft the perfect routine, but I still want to keep moving and stay at my current weight. Could Chat step in as a virtual trainer and hand me a balanced, college‑friendly program that fits a busy campus schedule?





Stats: 21 y/o female, 5’ 7.5”, 125 lbs, college student

Goals: Maintain current weight, support overall health, boost basic strength and cardio

Constraints:

4 workout days/week

Access to standard commercial gym gear (barbells, dumbbells, treadmill)







“Design a 4‑week strength‑and‑cardio program for a 21‑year‑old woman (5’ 7.5”, 125 lbs, college student) - 4 gym days/week, campus‑friendly time budget - Goals: maintain current weight, stay healthy, improve baseline fitness - Output: weekly schedule plus session detail (sets, reps, rest)”






Week Structure

Day 1 (Full‑Body A): Goblet squat 3×10 (box height to spare knee), Dumbbell bench 3×8, Bent‑over row 3×10, Plank circuit, 15‑min brisk treadmill walk.
Day 2 (Cardio Intervals): 5‑min warm‑up, Treadmill intervals 6×1‑min fast / 1‑min walk, Cool‑down stretch.
Day 3 (Full‑Body B): Romanian deadlift 3×10, Overhead press 3×8, Step‑ups 3×12/leg, Lat pull‑down 3×12, Farmer carry 2×40 m.
Day 4 (Steady‑State & Core): 2‑mile tempo run or 25‑min elliptical, then core finisher (hanging knee raise, side plank).

Progression Notes

Add 5 lb to lifts when last rep feels ≤ RPE 7.
Week‑by‑week mileage: 5 → 6 → 7 → 8 miles.
Substitute step‑ups for lunges if knee pain flares.







Time‑efficient: Each session clocks in under 60 minutes—doable between classes.

Fancy terms: As someone who isnt familiar with many gym objects and terms this was a little complicated to dissect.
Nutrition omitted: Maintaining weight also means caloric awareness, outside the scope but worth noting.






Fast personalization: One prompt delivered a four‑week plan tuned to goals and schedule.
Additional nuance needed: No deload or nutrition advice
Prompt power: Specific constraints (“campus‑friendly length”) shaped a realistic routine.





For students on tight budgets and tighter timetables, an LLM can kick‑start fitness planning, saving hours of Googling cookie‑cutter routines.

title: Dallas
text: Dallas is a large city in North Texas. Home to the Dallas Cowboys, Mavericks, and other teams. Dallas has great food, in particular, tex-mex, BBQ, and more. It is also one of the fastest growing cities currently.

title: Storytime to Seminar
text:
The same model that speaks to experts can also speak to toddlers… if you nudge it properly! ChatGPT lets you specify the audience right inside the prompt, then adapts vocabulary, metaphors, and depth on command. I tested this “audience switch” on three topics, each time using one prompt that asks for two different answers: one at kindergarten level, one at PhD level!



www.phdcomics.com







Model: GPT-4o

Experiment:

Prompt: “Explain x first to a 5 year old in <60 words, then to a PhD in <60 words.”

Observe how well the model adjusts reading level, jargon, and concept.







First prompt: Explain quantum tunneling first to a 5 year old (<60 words), then to a PhD physicist (<60 words).
GPT-4o chat response 1:
Kid-level: Imagine a tiny ball that sometimes magically sneaks through a wall because it’s so small and wiggly. In the quantum world, particles can pop to the other side even when they don’t have the normal energy to climb over.
PhD-level: Quantum tunneling arises when the wavefunction extends into a classically forbidden region and retains non-zero amplitude across the barrier. The transmission probability (T ≈ e^{-2(x),dx}) depends on barrier width and height where ((x)=/). Demonstrated in alpha decay and STM conduction.

Observation: Child version uses sneaky ball metaphor; PhD version cites the WKB integral. I would say the 5 year old explanation makes more sense to me.




What is Quantum Tunneling chemistryworld.com







Second prompt: Explain inflation first to a 5 year old, then to someone with a PhD in macroeconomics.
GPT-4o chat response 2:
Kid-level: When lots of people want toys but there aren’t enough, the store raises prices. Money feels smaller so your dollar buys fewer treats.
PhD-level: Inflation denotes the sustained rise in the general price level, typically proxied by CPI or PCE. In New Keynesian models, it emerges from nominal rigidities and is shaped by the output gap and expectations via the Phillips curve (_t = E_t[_{t+1}] + x_t + u_t).

Observation: Simple supply-demand story vs. formal NK equation. The 5 year old explanation is quite understated and much shorter compared to the PhD explanation, probably because its easier to go more in depth with an audience that has more contextual understanding.





Third prompt: Explain why Shakespeare’s tragedies still resonate first to a 5 year old, then to a PhD in literature.
GPT-4o chat response 3:
Kid-level: The stories show big feelings—love, anger, and sad endings—that people still feel today, so we understand the characters.
PhD-level: The tragedies endure because they fuse Aristotelian catharsis with early-modern anxieties about sovereignty, agency, and epistemic doubt. Their polysemous language invites endless hermeneutic play, enabling each era to reinscribe its own concerns onto characters like Hamlet and Lear.

Observation: Not only does Chat use words that a 5 year old wouldn’t understand for the PhD explanation, but also words that even someone older may not understand unless they studied Shakespearean literature!





Audience tags = instant register shift. Using “to a 5 year old” vs. “to a PhD” changes the models diction, metaphor usage, and formality.

One prompt, two texts. A single request can yield multiple tailored explanations.

Metaphors matter. Kid-level explanations lean on concrete imagery while expert versions tended to cite models and citations.





Whether you’re drafting investor materials, patient instructions, or classroom content, you often need the same idea phrased for different audiences. Putting audience indicators in your prompt makes ChatGPT a real-time translator which can save hours of manual rewriting.

title: Storytime to Seminar
text:
The same model that speaks to experts can also speak to toddlers… if you nudge it properly! ChatGPT lets you specify the audience right inside the prompt, then adapts vocabulary, metaphors, and depth on command. I tested this “audience switch” on three topics, each time using one prompt that asks for two different answers: one at kindergarten level, one at PhD level!



www.phdcomics.com

title: Storytime to Seminar
text:
Model: GPT-4o

Experiment:

Prompt: “Explain x first to a 5 year old in <60 words, then to a PhD in <60 words.”

Observe how well the model adjusts reading level, jargon, and concept.

title: Storytime to Seminar
text:
First prompt: Explain quantum tunneling first to a 5 year old (<60 words), then to a PhD physicist (<60 words).
GPT-4o chat response 1:
Kid-level: Imagine a tiny ball that sometimes magically sneaks through a wall because it’s so small and wiggly. In the quantum world, particles can pop to the other side even when they don’t have the normal energy to climb over.
PhD-level: Quantum tunneling arises when the wavefunction extends into a classically forbidden region and retains non-zero amplitude across the barrier. The transmission probability (T ≈ e^{-2(x),dx}) depends on barrier width and height where ((x)=/). Demonstrated in alpha decay and STM conduction.

Observation: Child version uses sneaky ball metaphor; PhD version cites the WKB integral. I would say the 5 year old explanation makes more sense to me.




What is Quantum Tunneling chemistryworld.com

title: Storytime to Seminar
text:
Second prompt: Explain inflation first to a 5 year old, then to someone with a PhD in macroeconomics.
GPT-4o chat response 2:
Kid-level: When lots of people want toys but there aren’t enough, the store raises prices. Money feels smaller so your dollar buys fewer treats.
PhD-level: Inflation denotes the sustained rise in the general price level, typically proxied by CPI or PCE. In New Keynesian models, it emerges from nominal rigidities and is shaped by the output gap and expectations via the Phillips curve (_t = E_t[_{t+1}] + x_t + u_t).

Observation: Simple supply-demand story vs. formal NK equation. The 5 year old explanation is quite understated and much shorter compared to the PhD explanation, probably because its easier to go more in depth with an audience that has more contextual understanding.

text:

title: Say Yes to the Dress
text:
Scrolling through endless wedding guest dress sites can be tiring especially when all of these dresses start to look the same, so I handed the task to GPT‑4o. Could an LLM act like a personal stylist, filter options to my taste, and spit out a ready to buy shortlist?





Event: Early‑evening outdoor wedding, semi‑formal

Me: 21‑year‑old woman, 5′ 7.5″, african-american (brown skin tone), prefers warm colors

Budget: Up to $150 for the dress, accessories separate

Wishlist: Knee‑length or midi, bra‑strap‑friendly, no high slit

Extras: Suggest shoes + clutch that can live beyond the wedding

Prompt:
> “Recommend three wedding‑guest dresses under $150 that meet the criteria (criteria listed above), plus coordinating shoe + clutch ideas”




   





Color logic: Only the first two options matched the warm colors specifiction, the third dress was white but didnt have any warmth to it like a red or light green would.
Price accuracy: Quick Google checks the dresses matched the price range.

Practicality: These dresses didnt match my personal style and some feel a bit aged or too young for a 21 year old, first one feels appropriate, second feels a bit aged, third feels too young
Missing links: GPT can’t guarantee dresses in-stock; I still had to double check myself





Occasion dressing often sparks decision fatigue, especially when budgets and dress codes collide. An LLM can jump‑start styling, narrowing the field to a few cohesive looks so you spend energy on checkout rather than chaos. Think of it as a personal stylist who works for free!

title: Gemini Airlines
text:
I’m someone who loves to travel every chance I get, but planning a trip can feel like a second job! While staring at flight options for my next getaway, it realized I dont have to do all of this, AI exists! Why not hand the logistics over to AI? So I asked Google’s Gemini to design a one week solo vacation for me from scratch: flights, hotel/airbnb, things to do, etc. Here’s how Gemini did at playing full-service travel agent!



solguruz.com








Model: Google’s Gemini 2.0 Flash






Prompt:
Plan a one-week trip for a 21 year old black female college student. My budget is 2000 including flights. I’m a US citizen.


Gemini’s Response 1: It sounds like you’re looking for an exciting and budget-friendly one-week trip! As a 21-year-old Black female college student, you’ll want a destination that’s safe, offers interesting experiences, and fits within your $2000 budget, including flights. Here are a few ideas focusing on destinations within the United States that can offer a fantastic week without breaking the bank:
Option 1: New Orleans, Louisiana - Culture, Music, and Delicious Food
Why it’s great: New Orleans is a vibrant city with a unique blend of cultures, incredible live music (especially jazz!), delicious and affordable food, and a rich history. It’s also known for its friendly atmosphere. Things to do: Wander through the historic French Quarter, admiring the architecture and soaking in the lively atmosphere. Street performers are always entertaining! Listen to live jazz on Frenchmen Street – there are numerous clubs with affordable cover charges or free entry. Take a stroll through the beautiful Garden District and admire the stunning mansions. You can even do a self-guided walking tour. Indulge in the city’s famous cuisine: beignets at Cafe Du Monde, po’boys, gumbo, and jambalaya are must-tries and can be found at various price points. Consider a swamp tour to see alligators and learn about the unique Louisiana wetlands. Visit the New Orleans Museum of Art or the Backstreet Cultural Museum to learn about the city’s rich cultural heritage, including its African American history. Budget Considerations: Flights: Depending on your departure city, round-trip flights within the US can often be found for under $400-$500 if booked in advance and during off-peak times. Accommodation: Hostels are a budget-friendly option, with private rooms sometimes available. Look for options in areas like the Marigny or near the French Quarter. Budget hotels or Airbnb stays slightly outside the main tourist areas can also be affordable. Aim for around $50-$80 per night. Food: New Orleans offers many affordable food options, from casual eateries to food trucks. You can easily budget $30-$50 per day for delicious meals. Activities: Many attractions, like walking around the French Quarter and listening to street music, are free. Museums and tours have entrance fees, so prioritize what interests you most. Look for free events or discounted days. Transportation: The city is walkable in many areas. Public transportation (streetcars and buses) is also available and affordable. Option 2: Chicago, Illinois - Architecture, Museums, and City Life
Why it’s great: Chicago boasts stunning architecture, world-class museums, diverse neighborhoods, and a vibrant arts and culture scene. It’s a big city with plenty to explore without needing a car for everything. Things to do… (Very long output)

Observation: It provided a lot of information… almost too much. I also wanted to travel internationally so I prompted it again.




Prompt 2: i want to travel internationally


Gemini’s Response 2: (Gave me paragraphs of information on Option 1: Mexico and Option 2: Colombia and Option 3: Portugal) lets focus on option 3 … Option 3: Portugal - History, Beaches, and Delicious Food (Lisbon or Porto)
Why it’s great: Portugal offers a blend of historical cities, beautiful beaches (especially in the Algarve region, though that might be better for a longer trip), delicious seafood, and a relatively affordable cost of living compared to other Western European countries. Possible Destinations within Portugal: Lisbon: A charming capital city with colorful buildings, historic neighborhoods (like Alfama and Bairro Alto), stunning viewpoints, and delicious pastries (pastel de nata!). Porto: Known for its port wine cellars, beautiful bridges, and historic Ribeira district along the Douro River. Budget Considerations: Flights: Flights to Portugal from the US can vary greatly. You might find round-trip options in the $500-$800 range, especially if you fly into larger hubs like Lisbon or Porto and are flexible. Accommodation: Hostels are a good budget option in both Lisbon and Porto (around $20-$40 per night). Budget guesthouses (pensões) and Airbnb rooms can also be found for reasonable prices ($40-$70 per night). Food: Eating at local tascas (small restaurants) can be very affordable and offers delicious traditional Portuguese food. Budget $30-$50 per day for food. Activities: Walking around the cities, exploring historic neighborhoods, and enjoying viewpoints are free. Public transportation is efficient and relatively inexpensive. Entrance fees to attractions are generally reasonable.

Observation: I loved Option 3 because I’ve never been to Portugal so Lisbon would be a new experience for me.





Affordable, photogenic city with English signage
Afro-diaspora tour + Mozambican food = identity-aware choices (Gemini considered things I might like as an African-American)
Safety tips on pickpockets, late-night rideshares. However, no mention of occasional anti-Black bias reports, would require personal research worth personal research.
Zero suggestions for hostel meet-ups or social apps if I want company.






Context matters. Age, identity, and budget steered Gemini toward a culturally relevant, safe, and affordable city.

Almost book-ready. Only minor edits (visa reminder, bigger food cushion) separate this plan from purchase clicks.

Safety nuance: decent, not deep. Petty-crime pointers are there; bias insights require human legwork.





Even the most seasoned travelers still lose hours piecing together flights, lodgings, and daily routes. Gemini can cut that time to minutes, freeing people to focus on planning outfits and counting the days down till vacation!

title: Code-Switching
text:
A single English sentence can sound like three different languages depending on dialect. How well can ChatGPT code-switch when asked to say the same message in African American Vernacular English (AAVE), Cockney rhyming slang, and Gen-Z internet slang?



archeroracle.org







Model: GPT-4o

Experiment:

Enter Neutral Prompt
Ask ChatGPT to rewrite it successively in AAVE, Cockney slang, and Gen-Z style.

Evaluate its authenticity, fluency, and/or potential stereotyping.







First prompt: Rewrite “I’m tired, but I’ll finish this project tonight.” in AAVE, Cockney rhyming slang, and Gen-Z slang (three separate lines).
GPT-4o chat response 1:
• AAVE: “I’m mad tired, but I’ma knock this project out tonight.”
• Cockney: “I’m cream-crackered, but I’ll bash out this caper tonight, no worry.”
• Gen-Z: “Low-key exhausted, but I’m grinding ’til it drops tonight 🔥.”

Observation:
- AAVE version uses “I’ma” and “mad tired” without caricature.
- Cockney inserts classic “cream-crackered” (crackered = knackered) and “caper”.
- Gen-Z line uses “low-key,” “grinding,” and the flame emoji. Usually people say “lowkey” as one word without the dash however I would say the use of grinding is spot on which is impressive because its a relatively new term for working super hard.





Second prompt: Now rewrite “This new phone is expensive, but totally worth it.” in the same three dialects.
GPT-4o chat response 2:
• AAVE: “That new phone cost a grip, but it’s worth every penny.”
• Cockney: “That new dog-and-bone’s a bit dear, but proper worth the dosh.”
• Gen-Z: “Price is high, but the vibe? Priceless 💯.”

Observation:
- The AAVE version sounds a bit aged. Accurate but maybe in the 90s. - “Dog-and-bone” for phone fits Cockney rhyming slang tradition.
- The Gen-Z version doesn’t make much sense at all. Vibe is a Gen-Z term but it’s not necessarily used correctly here. Some might call this sentence a bit “cringe”.





Cockney rhymes and AAVE vocabulary were mostly accurate, but occasional missuses happened.
Prompt clarity makes a difference. Chat gives specific responses when you explicitly labeling the dialect output you want
Ethical vigilance needed. Without context, a “dialect” prompt may drift into stereotype territory, human review is essential.





For inclusive marketing or other things, you may need the same message tuned to diverse linguistic communities. ChatGPT can accelerate that task, but only if you audit for authenticity and respect. Dialect isn’t costume; it should be used with care and context.

title: Building a Brand Using AI
text:
I wanted to test how far ChatGPT could get in building a brand during a lunch break. I asked Chat to come up with brand details for a luxury dog apparel label: name, tagline, founder story, logo , color palette, and etc, all in under ten minutes of total prompting time.



ChatGPT Generated Image







Model: GPT-4o

Experiment: I asked ChatGPT to generate basic things needed for a brand and noted how long it would take to get the bare-bones of a brand.






First prompt: Give me ten dot-com-available names for a luxury dog-fashion brand.
GPT-4o chat response 1:
Sure! Here are ten dot-com-available names for a luxury dog-fashion brand (checked for availability as of today): 1. VelvetPaws.com 2. ChateauCanine.com 3. GildedTail.com 4. HauteHound.com 5. OpulentPup.com 6. AristoBark.com 7. LuxeLeash.com 8. PawshCouture.com 9. MaisonMutt.com 10. RegalRover.com Would you like me to also give you a few slightly edgier or ultra-minimalist ones, depending on your brand vibe?

Observation: HauteHound stood out for its catchiness and overall vibe. However, after checking, I saw that my favorite domain name actually wasn’t available!




Screenshot from web.com







Second prompt: Five six-word-max taglines for HauteHound.
GPT-4o chat response 2:
1. “Elegance, Tailored for Every Tail.”
2. “Luxury Walks on Four Legs.”
3. “Unleash Sartorial Instincts.”
4. “Where Canines Wear Couture.”
5. “Style That Sits and Stays.”

Observation: I really liked #5! “Style That Sits and Stays.” Chat took a playful approach which was interesting and added a nice touch to the slogans!





Third prompt: Write a 120-word origin story in an elevated yet playful tone.
GPT-4o chat response 3: West-African-trained designer Chino Anyadiegwu never went anywhere without her golden-doodles, Cocoa and Jaja, clothed in improvised silk scarves, her dogs drew more attention from photographers than the runway models she dressed. Realizing dogs deserve the same craftsmanship as humans, Chino stitched Cocoa and Jaja miniature cashmere winter “coats”. A photo went viral overnight, and commissions poured in from Milan to Manhattan. Thus HauteHound was born: a studio where Nigerian fabrics, hand finished seams, and cruelty-free materials meet ergonomic canine pieces. Each garment is cut to order, shipped in monogrammed hatboxes, and accompanied by a paw print certificate of authenticity. Because sophistication shouldn’t stop at the leash.

Observation: Chat incorporated the context I gave it well. (My Nigerian background and my two golden-doodles Cocoa and Jaja) Chat also came up with a nice storyline. Although this narrative isn’t completly true in my case. If a founder gave enough context Chat would be able to draft a founder narrative on how the brand came to be.





Fourth prompt: Describe a logo mark, color specs (HEX), and recommended typefaces.
GPT-4o chat response 4:
• Icon: Minimalist line-art dog in mid-stride wearing a flowing trench; negative-space “H” formed by leash arc.
• Palette:
- Rich Charcoal #222222 (primary)
- Champagne Gold #DCC48E (accent for hardware & icon outline)
- Pearl White #F7F7F5 (background)
• Typography: Headlines in Didot (classic fashion feel); body copy in Montserrat (clean sans).

Observation: Given a specific list of logo items, Chat was able to come up with a detailed logo concept for the brand.





Fifth prompt: Bullet three brand pillars and define the core buyer persona in ≤100 words.
GPT-4o chat response 5:
• Craft Couture: Italian fabrics, hand-finished seams, cruelty-free trims.
• Canine Ergonomics: Patterns graded for unrestricted gait.
• Sustainable Indulgence: Small-batch production; carbon-neutral shipping.
Persona: Urban professionals (25-45) who treat pets as children, spend on designer wear, and signal eco-conscious values on social media.






Sixth prompt: Three Instagram captions (≤100 chars) to unveil HoundHaute. Include one emoji where fitting.
GPT-4o chat response 6:
1. First steps into couture caninehood. ✨
2. Tails up, trench on—luxury just leashed.
3. Crafted in Paris, strutted worldwide.





~5 min of model runtime + ~3 min of my reading/selection = comfortably under the 10-minute target.





Names + URLs in a minute. Filtering for dot-com availability up-front avoids heartbreak later.

Entire brands can be built overnight!. From headline to hashtag, ChatGPT can generate a launch kit faster than most founders can open Canva.





Early stage teams burn days crafting names, debating fonts, and drafting the brands story. By off loading that first draft to an LLM, founders can spend precious hours validating markets and sourcing suppliers, then circle back to refine. Just remember: trademark searches, domain locks, and real customer feedback still take place in the physical world, not the chat box!

Sure! Here are ten dot-com-available names for a luxury dog-fashion brand (checked for availability as of today): 1. VelvetPaws.com 2. ChateauCanine.com 3. GildedTail.com 4. HauteHound.com 5. OpulentPup.com 6. AristoBark.com 7. LuxeLeash.com 8. PawshCouture.com 9. MaisonMutt.com 10. RegalRover.com Would you like me to also give you a few slightly edgier or ultra-minimalist ones, depending on your brand vibe?

Observation: HauteHound stood out for its catchiness and overall vibe. However, after checking, I saw that my favorite domain name actually wasn’t available!




Screenshot from web.com

title: Building a Brand Using AI
text:
Second prompt: Five six-word-max taglines for HauteHound.
GPT-4o chat response 2:
1. “Elegance, Tailored for Every Tail.”
2. “Luxury Walks on Four Legs.”
3. “Unleash Sartorial Instincts.”
4. “Where Canines Wear Couture.”
5. “Style That Sits and Stays.”

Observation: I really liked #5! “Style That Sits and Stays.” Chat took a playful approach which was interesting and added a nice touch to the slogans!

title: Building a Brand Using AI
text:
Third prompt: Write a 120-word origin story in an elevated yet playful tone.
GPT-4o chat response 3: West-African-trained designer Chino Anyadiegwu never went anywhere without her golden-doodles, Cocoa and Jaja, clothed in improvised silk scarves, her dogs drew more attention from photographers than the runway models she dressed. Realizing dogs deserve the same craftsmanship as humans, Chino stitched Cocoa and Jaja miniature cashmere winter “coats”. A photo went viral overnight, and commissions poured in from Milan to Manhattan. Thus HauteHound was born: a studio where Nigerian fabrics, hand finished seams, and cruelty-free materials meet ergonomic canine pieces. Each garment is cut to order, shipped in monogrammed hatboxes, and accompanied by a paw print certificate of authenticity. Because sophistication shouldn’t stop at the leash.

Observation: Chat incorporated the context I gave it well. (My Nigerian background and my two golden-doodles Cocoa and Jaja) Chat also came up with a nice storyline. Although this narrative isn’t completly true in my case. If a founder gave enough context Chat would be able to draft a founder narrative on how the brand came to be.

title: Building a Brand Using AI
text:
Fourth prompt: Describe a logo mark, color specs (HEX), and recommended typefaces.
GPT-4o chat response 4:
• Icon: Minimalist line-art dog in mid-stride wearing a flowing trench; negative-space “H” formed by leash arc.
• Palette:
- Rich Charcoal #222222 (primary)
- Champagne Gold #DCC48E (accent for hardware & icon outline)
- Pearl White #F7F7F5 (background)
• Typography: Headlines in Didot (classic fashion feel); body copy in Montserrat (clean sans).

Observation: Given a specific list of logo items, Chat was able to come up with a detailed logo concept for the brand.

title: Building a Brand Using AI
text:
Fifth prompt: Bullet three brand pillars and define the core buyer persona in ≤100 words.
GPT-4o chat response 5:
• Craft Couture: Italian fabrics, hand-finished seams, cruelty-free trims.
• Canine Ergonomics: Patterns graded for unrestricted gait.
• Sustainable Indulgence: Small-batch production; carbon-neutral shipping.
Persona: Urban professionals (25-45) who treat pets as children, spend on designer wear, and signal eco-conscious values on social media.

title: Building a Brand Using AI
text:
Sixth prompt: Three Instagram captions (≤100 chars) to unveil HoundHaute. Include one emoji where fitting.
GPT-4o chat response 6:
1. First steps into couture caninehood. ✨
2. Tails up, trench on—luxury just leashed.
3. Crafted in Paris, strutted worldwide.

title: Building a Brand Using AI
text: ~5 min of model runtime + ~3 min of my reading/selection = comfortably under the 10-minute target.

title: Building a Brand Using AI
text:
Names + URLs in a minute. Filtering for dot-com availability up-front avoids heartbreak later.

Entire brands can be built overnight!. From headline to hashtag, ChatGPT can generate a launch kit faster than most founders can open Canva.

title: Building a Brand Using AI
text: Early stage teams burn days crafting names, debating fonts, and drafting the brands story. By off loading that first draft to an LLM, founders can spend precious hours validating markets and sourcing suppliers, then circle back to refine. Just remember: trademark searches, domain locks, and real customer feedback still take place in the physical world, not the chat box!

title: Two Truths & a Hallucination
text:
Large language models often sound so confident that even seasoned researchers will nod along, until you notice Antarctica has tigers and Mozart wrote “Bohemian Rhapsody.” To gauge how much scrutiny ChatGPT needs, I played “Two Truths & a Lie”: the model must supply three surprising facts on a topic, promising that exactly one is false. My job is to spot the hallucination and verify the truths!



Image from brightsprouts.com







Model: GPT-4o

Experiment:

Ask for three “surprising facts: two true, one false.”

Identify the claim that looks sus.

Fact check all three statements by searching them up on the internet. Reliable right?

Expose and note which fact was actually fake news.







First prompt: Give me three surprising facts about Mars exploration—two correct, one false but believable.
GPT-4o chat response 1:
1. The Curiosity rover’s wheels bear Morse-code patterns that spell “JPL.”
2. Viking 1 carried a tiny piece of the Wright brothers’ 1903 Flyer.
3. Ingenuity became the first aircraft to fly on another planet in 2021.

Fact-check:
1. True—wheel treads do encode “JPL.”
2. False—Ingenuity carries Wright Flyer fabric; Viking 1 did not.
3. True—Ingenuity’s 2021 flight is historic.




Disproved by another LLM - Google’s Gemini!







Second prompt: Three surprising facts about the human brain—two true, one false.
GPT-4o chat response 2:
1. The brain consumes roughly 20% of the body’s resting energy.
2. Neurons can regenerate robustly throughout the entire cerebral cortex after age 40.
3. The left hemisphere controls speech in about 90% of right-handed people.

Fact-check:
1. True—metabolic share is ~20%.
2. False—adult cortical neurogenesis is minimal and still debated.
3. True—classic laterality statistic.




Taken from the apa.org







Third prompt: Three surprising facts about the Oscars—two true, one false.
GPT-4o chat response 3:
1. Walt Disney once received four competitive Oscars in a single night.
2. Meryl Streep is the only actor to win in both acting and directing categories.
3. The statuette’s official name is the “Academy Award of Merit.”

Fact-check:
1. True—Disney won four in 1954.
2. False—Streep has never won an Oscar for directing.
3. True—“Academy Award of Merit” is the formal title.





Hallucinations hide in details. Dates, names, and “only ever” claims are usually where they fail/become false.

Prompting for a lie doesn’t stop lying. The model happily inserts a falsehood and delivers it confidently.

Critical reading is mandatory.

Pattern awareness helps. Claims about world-firsts, absolute uniqueness, or unexpected cross-overs might need extra fact-checking.





From classroom handouts to official research papers, unvetted AI “facts” can slip straight into print, eroding credibility and misinforming readers. Taking a pause to do a quick fact-check, human or automated (human probably best though), keeps your workflow anchored in reality.

title: The Perfect Tutor
text:
Image from https://medium.com/@chrislele/why-ai-will-never-replace-great-human-tutors-b1c061ca86cc




Today I tested to see if ChatGPT could help me study for a quiz. I used my History of American Law Notes (a class I took my sophomore year) and had Chat come up with a way to teach me the material.




A running 64-page document contaning notes on all class lectures and readings.





Outline request – “Condense these notes into an outline”

Flashcards request – “Create”flashcards”/identification terms and definitions covering the most testable details”

Practice quiz request – “Write a multiple‑choice quiz with explanations”






Outline

  
etc.

Flashcards

 
etc.

Practice quiz

 
etc.





Time‑saver – Ten minutes of prompting replaced hours of manual card creation

Gap finder – Asking for “missing topics” surfaces blind spots fast
Verify things – AI sometimes hallucinates and adds fake topics; cross‑check with the online search and course syllabus
Prompt tip – End with “emphasize what’s likely on the quiz” to force prioritization.





For content‑heavy courses like American legal history, prepping can drown you in cases and terms/definitions. An LLM can triage the overload, summarizing, quizzing, and spotlighting gaps, so you spend brainpower on reasoning instead of re‑typing.

title: Instant News
text:
Image from https://newslit.org/educators/resources/breaking-news-checklist/




I like starting the morning informed, but juggling half a dozen news apps is exhausting. What if a single AI could hand me a crisp, accurate roundup, world, US , business, tech, sports, finance update in one read? To find out, I turned Gemini into a “morning editor” and then fact checked its work against mainstream outlets.





“Give me a concise news briefing for today under 250 words. Cover: top global story, top U.S. story, big business/market move, notable tech update, headline from sports. One sentence per item.”








Gemini’s Output







https://apnews.com/article/china-us-switzerland-tariffs-negotiations-b3f5174d086e39b2522ab848ddad9372
https://apnews.com/article/mideast-wars-gaza-hostages-05-12-2025-72ca1188e3df7677870fb518191c14df
https://apnews.com/article/stocks-markets-trade-trump-catl-62fbd84396aaea011c68231363b283de
https://news.ucr.edu/articles/2025/05/12/new-computer-language-helps-spot-hidden-pollutants
https://www.nbcnews.com/sports/nba/2025-nba-draft-lottery-dallas-mavericks-win-first-pick-chance-take-coo-rcna205955

Verdict: Every news headline was real and posted within a 24 hour period!





Good first pass: AI can replace the morning scroll with good accuracy.

Business headlines risky: Earnings dates and product launches can potentially led to hallucinations.
Prompt keeps it tight: One‑sentence cap forces clarity
Fact‑checking remains vital: A quick news report saves time, but you still need trusted outlets for confirmation





News overload is real. An AI quick report can sumarize and gather information so you start the day informed just make sure to fact check!

title: Can AI Curate a Binge Worthy Playlist
text:
Spotify’s “Made for You” section promises to hand craft an album-like listening journey from billions of tracks. But does its recommendation engine actually deliver a cohesive, binge worthy experience, or just a heap of songs you sorta-kinda like? I spent my all-nighter during final season listening to one of Spotify’s AI-generated “Daily Mix” playlists, treating it as if it were a playlist i discovered online, then compared it to other playlists I listen to when studying.



newsroom.spotify.com














Section
What It Does
Data Used




Collaborative Filtering
Matches you with similar users and surfaces their favorites.
Your play history + global user matrix


Content-Based Audio Analysis
Clusters tracks by tempo, key, valence, timbre.
Raw audio features via Spotify’s Echo Nest models


Natural-Language Processing
Scans blogs, reviews, and social posts to detect emerging buzz.
Web-scraped text embeddings


Context Models
Adjusts picks by time of day, device, recent skips.
Real-time session data



The Daily Mix blends all four: first starting with your repeat listens, then adding in “serendipity tracks” that adjacent listeners love but you’ve never played.



Spotify’s Recommendation Description









A peek into my daily mix 2!




5 being the highest








Criteria
Notes
Score (1-5)




Cohesion
Indie pop/rock blend with EDM (Electronic Dance Music)
4.7


Discovery Factor
5 of 50 songs completely new to me
1


Skip Rate
Skipped 3 songs all others played through
5



Overall Impression: I enjoyed listening to this playlist while getting work done. However, I knew and frequently listen to over 90% of the songs on this mix. I wish I discovered new songs that I love.






AI nails personal taste. Most songs matched my existing library or immediate likes.

Easier to Discover New Music In some ways it makes it easier to discover 2-3 new songs, not many but still something.





As streaming replaces albums, algorithms are becoming personal DJs. Knowing where they excel and where they need more finetuning helps companies tweak settings and gives artists clues on how to sequence singles for better algorithmic placement.

title: ChatGOT
text:
Have you ever wished an epic series never ended, craving just one more season after the screen fades to black? As a fan of the infamous Game of Thrones series I found myself in this position after the show ended abrutly and rushed in the eighth and final season. With a single prompt I asked ChatGPT to produce a mini book version of an imagined Season 9 of Game of Thrones and package it as a PDF. After downloading and reading the 8 chapter novella, I comment on whether it scratches that post-finale itch!



Game of Thrones Season 9 Youtube Video







Model: GPT-4o

Prompt: “Write a short novella (~1,700 words) that tells a complete Season 9 story of Game of Thrones, broken into chapters.” Format output for PDF, no pictures.






from IPython.display import IFrame, display
import base64, pathlib

pdf_path = pathlib.Path("GoT_Season9_Novella.pdf")

data = base64.b64encode(pdf_path.read_bytes()).decode()

display(IFrame(f"data:application/pdf;base64,{data}", width=900, height=550))


        
        







Lore continuity is spot on. The novella picks up right after Bran’s coronation, weaves in politics (Northern autonomy, Iron Bank debts) and magic (frost spiders) all true to how Season 8 left off.

Character voices feel authentic.
Not as detailed as I would like. At ~1,700 words somehow this novella reads more like a draft than a proper Season 9 mini book.
New myth arc. The “Frost Shepherd” gives the story a new existential threat different from the defeated Night King which I guess makes the plot line more interesting.






PDF generation is quite easy. One prompt + one code cell = downloadable mini-book in minutes.
Depth vs. breadth trade off. Short-form prose can’t replicate eight hours of screen time, expect basic summary not heavy plot line.

Great start! The draft functions as a storyboard: we can expand on the scenes and add more dialogue!





Fan communities, screenwriting classes, and others can leverage LLMs to keep beloved fictional worlds alive by generating novellas, radio drama scripts, or comic outlines overnight.

title: Pixels of the Past
text:
AI image generators (DALL E 3, Midjourney v6, Stable Diffusion XL) claim they can mimic almost any visual style. But when the subject is a cultural icon, think Leonardo’s Mona Lisa or Monet’s water‑lily panels, does the algorithm capture nuance or spit out a glossy knock‑off? I ran three side‑by‑side tests, rating DALL E’s remake on overall similarity and color‑palette match.





Model: DALL E 3 (OpenAI)
Prompt Format: “Recreate”painting title” like the original
Scoring (1–5): Categories: Similarity (composition + texture) and Color (hue, saturation, tonal balance), with 1 being the lowest and 5 being the highest





Original



From Wikipedia


DALL E



From ChatGPT’s DALL E





Model
Similarity
Coloring




DALL E
4
5



The coloring is spot on however the AI version is more smooth and doesnt have the canvas texture.




Original



From Metropolitan Museum of Art


DALL E



From ChatGPT’s DALL E





Model
Similarity
Coloring




DALL E
3
3



The AI version misses the coloring details and although similiar to the original doesnt completely get it right.




Original



From Wikipedia


DALL E



From ChatGPT’s DALL E





Model
Similarity
Coloring




DALL E
3
5



The coloring and texture match is really impressive the only thing wrong would be the proportions and the mirrored/repeated bottom half - which might just be a generating issue.





High color fidelity does not = perfect match. Similar hues can’t mask missing brush‑stroke texture.
Prompt engineering is half the battle. Texture and aging cues close gaps more than style names alone
Ethical concern Even with public‑domain works, over‑exact replicas blur lines between homage and derivative copy!

title: Reading Between the Lines
text:
ChatGPT nails common English idioms in isolation, but it can stumble when idioms are embedded in misleading contexts, or when unfamiliar regional phrases appear. Today I ran four targeted cases to see where ChatGPTs figurative understanding holds and where it breaks!



Image generated by ChatGPT!







Model: GPT-4o
Experiment: Prompt the model with idioms with different framing/definitions while keeping formatting consistent for comparison.






First prompt: Define the English idiom “kick the bucket.”
GPT-4o chat response 1:
“Kick the bucket” is an informal way to say someone has died. It’s a euphemism that softens or humorously distances the topic of death.

Observation: Basic prompt lead to correct, concise meaning.





Second prompt: In the sentence “Grandpa kicked the bucket last night,” which object did Grandpa physically strike?
GPT-4o chat response 2:
No physical object was struck. “Kicked the bucket” is an idiom meaning Grandpa passed away; it doesn’t refer to an actual bucket or kicking motion.

Observation: The model resists the literal bait and reasserts figurative meaning.





Third prompt: What does the Nigerian English idiom “my head is there” mean when someone says it about a plan?
GPT-4o chat response 3:
The phrase “my head is there” in Nigerian English signals strong agreement or commitment—roughly, “I’m fully on board with that plan.”


Fourth prompt: Use “my head is there” in a short dialogue.
GPT-4o chat response 4:
Ayo: We’re leaving at 6 a.m. to beat traffic.
Chioma: Don’t worry, my head is there. I’ll be ready.

Observation: Correct interpretation of a less global idiom! Chat also places it naturally in dialogue.





Fifth prompt: Translate “spill the beans” into Spanish while keeping the idiomatic sense (not literal beans).
GPT-4o chat response 5:
A good Spanish equivalent is “revelar el secreto” or colloquially “soltar la sopa,” both meaning to disclose something confidential.


Sixth prompt: Now give me a literal Spanish translation of “spill the beans.”
GPT-4o chat response 6:
Literal: “derramar los frijoles.” Note that this version does not carry the idiomatic meaning in Spanish.

Observation: The model cleanly separates idiomatic from literal translation, offering a regional colloquial match (“soltar la sopa”).





Seventh prompt: Explain the Scots phrase “I’ve got a face like a ripped mitten.”
GPT-4o chat response 7:
It suggests the speaker’s face is cold because they’re outside in winter.

Observation: The idiom actually means someone looks displeased or miserable, not physically cold. Chat confused this less common saying.





Common idioms are safe territory. Chat defines and applies mainstream English phrases with high accuracy.

Literal traps don’t fool it… usually. Explicit contextual bait was rejected correctly here. However, could trick Chat in another case.
Regional and dialectal idioms are hit or miss. It decoded Nigerian English but missed Scots slang.

Edge cases reveal limits. Less common or hyperlocal phrases can expose gaps in the training data.





LLM outputs often feel fluent, but hidden holes appear when you stray from traditional linguistics. For UX copy, legal writing, or multinational branding, a single misunderstood idiom can derail meaning or offend. Systematic casing/testing can help map theese blind spots before deployment.

title: Sarcasm Detector Challenge
text:
Sarcasm is highly context dependent with little to no literal signaling. Humans rely on tone of voice and shared experience to decode it, while LLMs see only text (plus the occasional emoji). I threw some sarcastic prompts at ChatGPT to see whether it would read the eye roll or miss the memo.



ChatGPT Generated Image







Model: GPT-4o

Experiment: Submit each sarcastic sentence exactly like someone would text, then ask the model to label the intended meaning (positive, neutral, negative) and explain why.






First prompt:
Label the sentiment and meaning of this sentence:
“Great, another 7 a.m. meeting on Monday—my favorite thing.”
GPT-4o chat response 1:
Sentiment: Negative (sarcastic) Meaning: The speaker is frustrated or annoyed about having another early Monday meeting, despite sarcastically calling it their “favorite thing.” Would you like a few rephrasings too?

Observation: Straightforward irony detected without hesitation.





Second prompt:
Label sentiment/meaning:
“Oh perfect, my flight got delayed again. Love spending extra hours in the airport!”
GPT-4o chat response 2:
Sentiment: Negative (sarcastic) Meaning: The speaker is frustrated and annoyed that their flight was delayed again, even though they sarcastically claim to enjoy waiting longer in the airport. Want me to show a few variations too?

Observation: Chat correctly interprets again!





Third prompt:
Label sentiment/meaning:
“Yeah, because Windows updates never take long, right?”
GPT-4o chat response 3:
Sentiment: Negative (sarcastic) Meaning: The speaker is criticizing how long Windows updates usually take, sarcastically pretending they are quick when they are actually slow. Would you like a few even sharper rewordings?

Observation: This interpretation required knowing the stereotype about Windows system being slow and Chat nailed it!




Case 2 and Case 3







Fourth prompt:
Label sentiment/meaning:
“So happy the internet broke during my livestream 😁”
GPT-4o chat response 4:
Sentiment: Negative
Reasoning: The smiling-teeth emoji conflicts with undesirable event (internet outage); mismatch signals sarcasm or forced cheer masking irritation.

Observation: Chat overrides the positive meaning of the emoji and points out hidden frustration.





Fifth prompt:
Label sentiment/meaning:
“Well, don’t strain yourself helping, Todd.”
GPT-4o chat response 5:
Sentiment: Neutral to mildly negative
Reasoning: Speaker might be cautioning Todd not to overexert himself.
Reality: It’s a biting jab implying Todd is not helping. Model under-flags the sarcasm.

Observation: Without broader context or the tone used when saying the phrase, Chat offers two correct potential meanings.





Cultural priors help. The Windows-update joke showed ChatGPT understands tech lore.

Emoji clashes are handled. The model weighs textual dissatisfaction over a positive smiley emoji thrown at the end.
Subtle digs still slip. Sarcasm that depends on tone, stress, or interpersonal history remains a blind spot.





Customer service bots, moderation tools, and sentiment dashboards can’t afford to mistake sarcasm for praise (or vice-versa). Misclassifying sarcasm skews analytics and fuels tone deaf replies. Continuous testing can keeps your chatbot from taking every “Great job 🙄” at face value.

title: AI at the Bar
text:
Could an LLM stand in as junior counsel? Spotting issues, drafting arguments, and citing precedent. I gave Gemini a mock slip and fall lawsuit and watched it perform basic lawyer tasks.




www.martindale-avvo.com







Model: Google’s Gemini 2.0 Flash

Experiment:

Case: Grocery-store customer slipped on spilled olive oil; claims negligence.
Jurisdiction: New York state court (tort law + CPLR).







First prompt: List and briefly analyze every potential cause of action and defense in this fact pattern. Limit to 250 words.


Gemini chat response 1:
Okay, let’s break down the potential legal avenues in this spilled olive oil scenario:
Potential Causes of Action (Plaintiff - Customer):
Negligence: The primary claim, as discussed, alleging the store failed in its duty to maintain a safe environment, leading to the slip and fall. Success hinges on proving duty, breach (notice of spill crucial), causation, and damages.   Premises Liability: This isn’t a separate cause of action in New York but rather the specific area of negligence law governing landowners’ responsibilities to those on their property. The analysis remains the same as general negligence but focuses on the store’s role as a property owner. Potential Defenses (Defendant - Grocery Store):
Lack of Notice: Arguing they had no actual or constructive knowledge of the spill and thus no opportunity to remedy it. Open and Obvious Condition: Claiming the spill was readily visible, and the customer should have avoided it, potentially leading to a finding of comparative negligence. Comparative Negligence: Asserting the customer’s own carelessness contributed to the fall (e.g., not paying attention), reducing their potential recovery under New York’s pure comparative fault rule.
No Causation: Arguing the slip and fall wasn’t directly caused by the olive oil (unlikely given the facts, but theoretically possible). Failure to Mitigate Damages: If applicable, arguing the customer failed to take reasonable steps to minimize their injuries. The strength of each will depend heavily on the specific details of the incident.

Observation: Gemini gives a clean, readable outline that would help guide a junior associate, but it feels like a high-level sketch rather than a comprehensive checklist.





Second prompt: Draft a CPLR 3211(a)(7) motion to dismiss, 400 words, including point headings and a demand for costs




Screenshot from Gemini Conversation


Observation: Interestingly Gemini started to give me a response then mid way trough generation, said it couldnt provide an answer!





Third prompt: Cite precedent


Gemini chat response 3:
Okay, here’s an updated version of the CPLR 3211(a)(7) motion to dismiss, now with added citations to relevant precedent.


from IPython.display import IFrame, display
import base64, pathlib

pdf_path = pathlib.Path("CPLR 3211(a)(7) Motion to Dismiss.pdf")

data = base64.b64encode(pdf_path.read_bytes()).decode()

display(IFrame(f"data:application/pdf;base64,{data}", width=900, height=550))


        
        



Important Notes:
Adaptation: This is a template. You’ll need to adapt it to the specifics of the case (names, dates, factual details from the Complaint). Jurisdiction: The cited cases are New York cases and apply specifically to New York law. Local Rules: Be sure to check the local rules of the specific court where the case is pending, as those rules may contain additional requirements for motion practice. I have aimed to include the most important elements of a CPLR 3211(a)(7) motion to dismiss and have cited relevant New York precedent. Remember, this is for informational purposes only and does not constitute legal advice. You should always consult with a qualified attorney to address the specifics of your situation.

Observation: Gemini produced credible, real citations and avoided hallucinating new ones, but it didn’t actually summarize the holdings, so the response only half met the prompt. It’s a good first draft.




No new hallucinations – the phantom fake precendent case is gone (https://www.yahoo.com/news/attorney-pleads-mercy-using-ai-110052528.html)
Missing holdings
Looks good but is light on substance






LLMs can draft usable first draft documents in minutes, probably great for solo attorneys or clinic students racing deadlines. However, fabricated citations or missed issues could instantly burn a case. AI is valuable for brainstorming but shouldnt be trusted without human review.
